IV FedMoD: Modeling and Problem Formulation

IV-A FL Time and Energy Consumption

1) FL Time: The constrained FL time at each global iteration consists of both computation and wireless transmission time that is explained below.

The wireless transmission time consists of (1) the uplink transmission time for transmitting the local updates from the UDs to the associated UAVs ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K}. This transmission time is already discussed in Section II-C and represented by Tusubscriptùëáùë¢T_{u}. (2) The transmission time for disseminating the local aggregated models among the UAVs. The model dissemination time among all the UAVs is Td‚Äãi‚Äãs‚Äãssubscriptùëáùëëùëñùë†ùë†T_{diss} as given in (10). (3) The downlink transmission time for transmitting the local aggregated models from the UAVs to the scheduled UDs ùí∞ùí∞\mathcal{U}. The downlink transmission time for UAV kùëòk can be expressed Tkd‚Äão=sRksubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëëùëúùëòùë†subscriptùëÖùëòT^{do}_{k}=\frac{s}{R_{k}}. On the other hand, the computation time for local learning at the uùë¢u-th UD is expressed as Tuc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp=Tl‚ÄãQu‚ÄãDufu,subscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëùùë¢subscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùë¢subscriptùê∑ùë¢subscriptùëìùë¢T^{comp}_{u}=T_{l}\frac{Q_{u}D_{u}}{f_{u}}, where TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l} is the number of local iterations to reach the local accuracy œµlsubscriptitalic-œµùëô\epsilon_{l} in the uùë¢u-th UD, QusubscriptùëÑùë¢Q_{u} as the number of CPU cycles to process one data sample, and fusubscriptùëìùë¢f_{u} is the computational frequency of the CPU in the uùë¢u-th UD (in cycles per second).

By combining the aforementioned components, the FL time œÑksubscriptùúèùëò\tau_{k} at the kùëòk-th UAV can be calculated as

œÑksubscriptùúèùëò\displaystyle\tau_{k} =maxu‚ààùí∞k‚Å°Tuc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp+maxu‚ààùí∞k‚Å°Tuc‚Äão‚Äãm+Tkd‚Äãoabsentsubscriptùë¢subscriptùí∞ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëùùë¢subscriptùë¢subscriptùí∞ùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùëáùëëùëúùëò\displaystyle=\max_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{k}}T^{comp}_{u}+\max_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{k}}T^{com}_{u}+T^{do}_{k}
=maxu‚ààùí∞k‚Å°{Tl‚ÄãQu‚ÄãDnfu}+maxu‚ààùí©k‚Å°{sRk,bu}+sRk.absentsubscriptùë¢subscriptùí∞ùëòsubscriptùëáùëôsubscriptùëÑùë¢subscriptùê∑ùëõsubscriptùëìùë¢subscriptùë¢subscriptùí©ùëòùë†superscriptsubscriptùëÖùëòùëèùë¢ùë†subscriptùëÖùëò\displaystyle=\max_{u\in\mathcal{U}_{k}}\left\{T_{l}\frac{Q_{u}D_{n}}{f_{u}}\right\}+\max_{u\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\left\{\frac{s}{R_{k,b}^{u}}\right\}+\frac{s}{R_{k}}. (18)

Therefore, the total FL time over all global iterations TùëáT is œÑ=T‚Äã(maxk‚ààùí¶‚Å°(œÑk)+Td‚Äãi‚Äãs‚Äãs)ùúèùëásubscriptùëòùí¶subscriptùúèùëòsubscriptùëáùëëùëñùë†ùë†\tau=T(\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}(\tau_{k})+T_{diss}), which should be no more than the maximum FL time threshold TmaxsubscriptùëámaxT_{\text{max}}. This constraint, over all global iterations TùëáT, is expressed as

œÑ=T(maxu‚ààùí©‚Å°{Tl‚ÄãQn‚ÄãDufu}‚èülocal learning+Tu‚èüuplink transmission+maxk‚ààùí¶‚Å°{sRk}‚èüdownlink transmission\displaystyle\tau=T\bigg{(}\underbrace{\max_{u\in\mathcal{N}}\left\{T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{u}}{f_{u}}\right\}}_{\text{local learning}}+\underbrace{T_{u}}_{\text{uplink transmission}}+\underbrace{\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\left\{\frac{s}{R_{k}}\right\}}_{\text{downlink transmission}}
+Td‚Äãi‚Äãs‚Äãs‚èüdissemination duration)‚â§Tmax.\displaystyle+\underbrace{T_{diss}}_{\text{dissemination duration}}\bigg{)}\leq T_{\text{max}}. (19)

2) Energy Consumption: The system‚Äôs energy is consumed for local model training at the UDs, wireless models transmission, and UAVs‚Äô hovering in the air.

1) Local computation: The well-known energy consumption model for the local computation is considered, where the energy consumption of the uùë¢u-th UD to process a single CPU cycle is Œ±‚Äãfu2ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùë¢\alpha f^{2}_{u}, and Œ±ùõº\alpha is a constant related to the switched capacitance [38, 39]. Thus, the energy consumption of the uùë¢u-th UD for local computation is Euc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp=Tl‚Äão‚Äãc‚ÄãCu‚ÄãDu‚ÄãŒ±‚Äãfu2.subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëùùë¢subscriptùëáùëôùëúùëêsubscriptùê∂ùë¢subscriptùê∑ùë¢ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëì2ùë¢E^{comp}_{u}=T_{loc}C_{u}D_{u}\alpha f^{2}_{u}.

2) Wireless models transmission: The energy consumption to transmit the local model parameters to the associated UAVs can be denoted by Euc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùë¢E^{com}_{u} and calculated as Euc‚Äão‚Äãm=Pu‚ÄãTuc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùë¢subscriptùëÉùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùë¢E^{com}_{u}=P_{u}T^{com}_{u}. Then, the total energy consumption Eusubscriptùê∏ùë¢E_{u} at the uùë¢u-th UD is Eu=Euc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp+Euc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptùê∏ùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëùùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùë¢E_{u}=E^{comp}_{u}+E^{com}_{u}. In a similar manner, the consumed energy for transmitting the local aggregated models back to the associated UDs can be denoted by Ekc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëòE^{com}_{k} and calculated as Ekc‚Äão‚Äãm=P‚ÄãTkc‚Äão‚Äãmsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëòùëÉsubscriptsuperscriptùëáùëêùëúùëöùëòE^{com}_{k}=PT^{com}_{k}.

3) UAV‚Äôs hovering energy: UAVs need to remain stationary in the air, thus most of UAV‚Äôs energy is consumed for hovering. The UAV‚Äôs hovering power is expressed as [40] ph‚Äão‚Äãv=(m‚Äãg)32‚ÄãœÄ‚Äãrp2‚Äãnp‚ÄãœÅ,superscriptùëù‚Ñéùëúùë£superscriptùëöùëî32ùúãsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëù2subscriptùëõùëùùúåp^{hov}=\sqrt{\frac{(mg)^{3}}{2\pi r_{p}^{2}n_{p}\rho}}, where mùëöm is UAV‚Äôs weight, gùëîg is the gravitational acceleration of the earth, rpsubscriptùëüùëùr_{p} is propellers‚Äô radius, npsubscriptùëõùëùn_{p} is the number of propellers, and œÅùúå\rho is the air density. In general, these parameters of all the UAVs are the same. The hovering time of the kùëòk-th UAV in each global iteration depends on œÑùúè\tau. Hence, the hovering energy of the kùëòk-th UAV can be calculated as Ekh‚Äão‚Äãv=ph‚Äão‚Äãv‚ÄãœÑtsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏‚Ñéùëúùë£ùëòsuperscriptùëù‚Ñéùëúùë£superscriptùúèùë°E^{hov}_{k}=p^{hov}\tau^{t}. In summary, the overall energy consumption of the kùëòk-th UAV and the uùë¢u-th UD, respectively, are

Ek=T‚Äã{Elh‚Äão‚Äãv+Elc‚Äão‚Äãm},Eu=T‚Äã{Euc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp+Euc‚Äão‚Äãm}.formulae-sequencesubscriptùê∏ùëòùëásubscriptsuperscriptùê∏‚Ñéùëúùë£ùëôsubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëôsubscriptùê∏ùë¢ùëásubscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëùùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùë¢\displaystyle E_{k}=T\left\{E^{hov}_{l}+E^{com}_{l}\right\},E_{u}=T\left\{E^{comp}_{u}+E^{com}_{u}\right\}. (20)

IV-B Problem Formulation

Given the ATIN and its FL time and energy components, our next step is to formulate the energy consumption minimization problem that involves the joint optimization of two sub-problems, namely UAV-LOS UD clustering and D2D scheduling sub-problems. To minimize the energy consumption at each global iteration, we need to develop a framework that decides: i) the UAV-UD clustering; ii) the adopted transmission rate of the UDs ùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãssubscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†\mathcal{U}_{los} to transmit their local models to the set of UAVs/RRBs; and iii) the set of D2D transmitters (relays) that helping the non-LOS UDs to transmit their local models to the set of UAVs ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K}. As such, the local models are delivered to all UAVs with minimum duration time, thus minimum energy consumption for UAV‚Äôs hovering and UD‚Äôs wireless transmission. Therefore, the energy consumption minimization problem in the ATIN can be formulated as follows.

P0:‚ÄãminRm‚Äãi‚Äãnu,ùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãs,ùí∞n‚Äão‚Äãn‚Äã‚àëk‚ààùí¶Ek+‚àëu‚ààùí∞EuP0:subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëÖùë¢ùëöùëñùëõsubscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†subscriptùí∞ùëõùëúùëõsubscriptùëòùí¶subscriptùê∏ùëòsubscriptùë¢ùí∞subscriptùê∏ùë¢\displaystyle\text{P0:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}R^{u}_{min},\mathcal{U}_{los},\mathcal{U}_{non}\end{subarray}}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}E_{k}+\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}E_{u}
s.t.{C1:‚Äãùí∞k,los‚à©ùí∞k‚Ä≤,los=‚àÖ,‚àÄ(k,k‚Ä≤)‚ààùí¶,C2:‚Äãùí∞k,los‚à©ùí∞u‚Ä≤,los=‚àÖ,‚àÄk‚ààùí¶,C3:‚Äãùí∞u,los‚à©ùí∞u‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,los=‚àÖ,C4:‚ÄãRk,bu‚â•R0,(u,k,b)‚àà(ùí∞,ùí¶,‚Ñ¨),C5:‚ÄãùöÉu^‚â§Tu,u‚ààùí∞los,C6:‚ÄãTidleu¬Ø‚â•(sRu^u¬Ø+sRk,bu¬Ø),u¬Ø‚ààùí∞los,u^‚ààùí∞non,C7:‚ÄãœÑ‚â§Tmax.formulae-sequencestcasesformulae-sequenceC1:subscriptùí∞klossubscriptùí∞superscriptk‚Ä≤losfor-allksuperscriptk‚Ä≤ùí¶otherwiseformulae-sequenceC2:subscriptùí∞klossubscriptùí∞superscriptu‚Ä≤losfor-allkùí¶otherwiseC3:subscriptùí∞ulossubscriptùí∞superscriptu‚Ä≤‚Ä≤losotherwiseformulae-sequenceC4:subscriptsuperscriptRukbsubscriptR0ukbùí∞ùí¶‚Ñ¨otherwiseformulae-sequenceC5:subscriptùöÉ^usubscriptTuusubscriptùí∞losotherwiseformulae-sequenceC6:subscriptsuperscriptT¬ØuidlessubscriptsuperscriptR¬Øu^ussubscriptsuperscriptR¬Øukbformulae-sequence¬Øusubscriptùí∞los^usubscriptùí∞nonotherwiseC7:ùúèsubscriptTmaxotherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}\text{C1:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathcal{U}_{k,los}\cap\mathcal{U}_{k^{\prime},los}=\emptyset,\forall(k,k^{\prime})\in\mathcal{K},\\ \text{C2:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathcal{U}_{k,los}\cap\mathcal{U}_{u^{\prime},los}=\emptyset,\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ \text{C3:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathcal{U}_{u,los}\cap\mathcal{U}_{u^{\prime\prime},los}=\emptyset,\\ \text{C4:}\hskip 5.69046ptR^{u}_{k,b}\geq R_{0},(u,k,b)\in(\mathcal{U},\mathcal{K},\mathcal{B}),\\ \text{C5:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathtt{T}_{\hat{u}}\leq T_{u},u\in\mathcal{U}_{los},\\ \text{C6:}\hskip 5.69046ptT^{\bar{u}}_{idle}\geq(\frac{s}{R^{\bar{u}}_{\hat{u}}}+\frac{s}{R^{\bar{u}}_{k,b}}),\bar{u}\in\mathcal{U}_{los},\hat{u}\in\mathcal{U}_{non},\\ \text{C7:}\hskip 5.69046pt\tau\leq T_{\text{max}}.\end{cases}

The constraints are explained as follows. Constraint C1 states that the set of scheduled UDs to the UAVs are disjoint, i.e., each UD must be scheduled to only one UAV. Constraints C2 and C3 make sure that each UD can be scheduled to only one relay and no user can be scheduled to a relay and UAV at the same time instant. Constraint C4 is on the coverage threshold of each UAV. Constraint C5 ensures that the local parameters of UD u^^ùë¢\hat{u} has to be delivered to UAV kùëòk via relay u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u} within sRm‚Äãi‚Äãnuùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖùë¢ùëöùëñùëõ\frac{s}{R^{u}_{min}}, i.e., ùöÉu^=sRu^u¬Ø+sRk,bu¬Ø‚â§sRm‚Äãi‚ÄãnusubscriptùöÉ^ùë¢ùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖ¬Øùë¢^ùë¢ùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖ¬Øùë¢ùëòùëèùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëÖùë¢ùëöùëñùëõ\mathtt{T}_{\hat{u}}=\frac{s}{R^{\bar{u}}_{\hat{u}}}+\frac{s}{R^{\bar{u}}_{k,b}}\leq\frac{s}{R^{u}_{min}}. Constraint C6 ensures that the idle time of UD u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u} is long enough for transmitting the local parameters of UD u^^ùë¢\hat{u} to UAV kùëòk. Constraint C7 is for the FL time threshold Tm‚Äãa‚Äãxsubscriptùëáùëöùëéùë•T_{max}. We can readily show that problem P0 is NP-hard. However, by analyzing the problem, we can decompose it into two sub-problems and solve them individually and efficiently.

IV-C Problem Decomposition

First, we focus on minimizing the energy consumption via efficient RRM scheduling of UDs ùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãssubscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†\mathcal{U}_{los} to the UAVs/RRBs. In particular, we can get the possible minimum transmission duration of UD u‚ààùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãsùë¢subscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†u\in\mathcal{U}_{los} by jointly optimizing the UD scheduling and rate adaptation in ùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãssubscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†\mathcal{U}_{los}. The mathematical formulation for minimizing the energy consumption via minimizing the transmission durations for UDs-UAVs/RRBs transmissions can be expressed as

P1:‚ÄãminRm‚Äãi‚Äãnu,ùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãs‚Äã‚àëk‚ààùí¶Ek+‚àëu‚ààùí∞EuP1:subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëÖùë¢ùëöùëñùëõsubscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†subscriptùëòùí¶subscriptùê∏ùëòsubscriptùë¢ùí∞subscriptùê∏ùë¢\displaystyle\text{P1:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}R^{u}_{min},\mathcal{U}_{los}\end{subarray}}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}E_{k}+\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}E_{u}
s.t.{(C1),(C4),(C5),(C7).formulae-sequencestcasesC1C4C5C7otherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}(\text{C1}),\hskip 5.69046pt(\text{C4}),\hskip 5.69046pt(\text{C5}),\hskip 5.69046pt(\text{C7}).\end{cases}

Note that this sub-problem contains UD-UAV/RRB scheduling and an efficient solution will be developed in Section IV-B.

After obtaining the possible transmission duration from UD-UAV transmissions, denoted by Tusubscriptùëáùë¢T_{u} of the uùë¢u-th UD (u‚ààùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãsùë¢subscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†u\in\mathcal{U}_{los}), by solving P1, we can now formulate the second sub-problem. In particular, we can minimize the energy consumption of non-LOS UDs ùí∞n‚Äão‚Äãnsubscriptùí∞ùëõùëúùëõ\mathcal{U}_{non} that are not been scheduled to the UAVs within Tusubscriptùëáùë¢T_{u} by using D2D communications via relaying mode. For this, UDs being scheduled to the UAVs from sub-problem P1 can be exploited to work as relays and schedule non-LOS UDs on D2D links within their idle times. Therefore, the second sub-problem of minimizing the energy consumption of unscheduled UDs to be scheduled on D2D links via relaying mode can be expressed as P2 as follows

P2:‚Äãminùí∞n‚Äão‚Äãn‚Äã‚àëk‚ààùí¶Ek+‚àëu‚ààùí∞EuP2:subscriptsubscriptùí∞ùëõùëúùëõsubscriptùëòùí¶subscriptùê∏ùëòsubscriptùë¢ùí∞subscriptùê∏ùë¢\displaystyle\text{P2:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathcal{U}_{non}\end{subarray}}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}E_{k}+\sum_{u\in\mathcal{U}}E_{u}
s.t.{(C2),(C3),(C5),(C6),C8:‚Äãùí©non‚ààùí´‚Äã(ùí∞\ùí©los).formulae-sequencestcasesC2C3C5C6C8:subscriptùí©nonùí´\ùí∞subscriptùí©losotherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}(\text{C2}),\hskip 5.69046pt(\text{C3}),\hskip 5.69046pt(\text{C5}),\hskip 5.69046pt(\text{C6}),\text{C8:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathcal{N}_{non}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{U}\backslash\mathcal{N}_{los}).\\ \end{cases}

Constraint C8 states that the set of relays is constrained only on the UDs that are not been scheduled to the UAVs. It can be easily observed that P2 is a D2D scheduling problem that considers selection of relays and their non-LOS scheduled UDs.

V FedMoD: Proposed Solution

V-A Solution to Subproblem P1: UAV-UD Clustering

Let ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} denote the set of all possible associations between UAVs, RRBs, and LOS UDs, i.e., ùíú=ùí¶√óùíµ√óùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãsùíúùí¶ùíµsubscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†\mathcal{A}=\mathcal{K}\times\mathcal{Z}\times\mathcal{U}_{los}. For instance, one possible association aùëéa in ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} is (k,z,u)ùëòùëßùë¢(k,z,u) which represents UAV kùëòk, RRB zùëßz, and UD uùë¢u. Let the conflict clustering graph in the network is denoted by ùí¢‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞)ùí¢ùí±‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}) wherein ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V} and ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} are the sets of vertices and edges of ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}, respectively. A typical vertex in ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G} represents an association in ùíúùíú\mathcal{A}, and each edge between two different vertices represents a conflict connection between the two corresponding associations of the vertices according to C1 in P1. Therefore, we construct the conflict clustering graph by generating a vertex v‚ààùí±ùë£ùí±v\in\mathcal{V} associated with a‚ààùíúùëéùíúa\in\mathcal{A} for UDs who have enough energy for performing learning and wireless transmissions. To select the UD-UAV/RRB scheduling that provides a minimum energy consumption while ensures C4 and C7 in P1, a weight w‚Äã(v)ùë§ùë£w(v) is assigned to each vertex v‚ààùí±ùë£ùí±v\in\mathcal{V}. For simplicity, we define the weight of vertex vk,uzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëòùë¢v^{z}_{k,u} as w‚Äã(vk,uz)=Euc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp+Euc‚Äão‚Äãmùë§subscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëòùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëùùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùë¢w(v^{z}_{k,u})=E^{comp}_{u}+E^{com}_{u}. Vertices vk,uzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëòùë¢v^{z}_{k,u} and vk‚Ä≤,u‚Ä≤z‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëß‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤v^{z^{\prime}}_{k^{\prime},u^{\prime}} are conflicting vertices that will be connected by an edge in ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} if one of the below connectivity conditions (CC) is satisfied:

  • ‚Ä¢

    CC1: (u=u‚Ä≤ùë¢superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤u=u^{\prime} and z=z‚Ä≤ùëßsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤z=z^{\prime} or k=k‚Ä≤ùëòsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤k=k^{\prime}). CC1 states that the same user uùë¢u is in both vertices vk,uzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëòùë¢v^{z}_{k,u} and vk‚Ä≤,u‚Ä≤z‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëß‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤v^{z^{\prime}}_{k^{\prime},u^{\prime}}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    CC2: (z=z‚Ä≤ùëßsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤z=z^{\prime} and u‚â†u‚Ä≤ùë¢superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤u\neq u^{\prime}). CC2 implies that the same RRB is in both vertices vk,uzsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëßùëòùë¢v^{z}_{k,u} and vk,u‚Ä≤z‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùëòsuperscriptùë¢‚Ä≤v^{z^{\prime}}_{k,u^{\prime}}.

Clearly, CC1 and CC2 correspond to a violation of the constraint C1 of P1 where two vertices are conflicting if: (i) the UD is associated with two different UAVs and(or) two different RRBs; or (ii) the RRB is associated with more than one UD. With the designed conflict clustering graph, P‚Äã1P1\text{P}1 is similar to MWIS problems in several aspects. In MWIS, two vertices should be non-adjacent in the graph (conditions CC1 and CC2 in Section¬†V-B), and similarly, in P1, same local learning user cannot be scheduled to two different UAVs or two different RRBs (i.e., C1). Moreover, the objective of problem P1 is to minimize the energy consumption, and similarly, the goal of MWIS is to select a number of vertices that have small weights. Therefore, the following theorem characterizes the solution to the energy consumption minimization problem P2 in an ATIN.
Theorem 2. The solution to problem P1 is equivalent to the minimum independent set weighting-search method, in which the weight of each vertex vùë£v corresponding to UD uùë¢u is

w‚Äã(v)=Euc‚Äão‚Äãm‚Äãp+Euc‚Äão‚Äãm.ùë§ùë£subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùëùùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùê∏ùëêùëúùëöùë¢\displaystyle w(v)=E^{comp}_{u}+E^{com}_{u}. (24)

Finding the minimum weight independent set Œì‚àósuperscriptŒì\Gamma^{*} among all other minimal sets in ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G} graph is explained as follows. First, we select vertex vi‚ààùí±,(i=1,2,‚ãØ,)v_{i}\in\mathcal{V},(i=1,2,\cdots,) that has the minimum weight w‚Äã(vi‚àó)ùë§subscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëñw(v^{*}_{i}) and add it to Œì‚àósuperscriptŒì\Gamma^{*} (at this point Œì‚àó={vi‚àó}superscriptŒìsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëñ\Gamma^{*}=\{v^{*}_{i}\}). Then, the subgraph ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚àó)ùí¢superscriptŒì\mathcal{G}(\Gamma^{*}), which consists of vertices in graph ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G} that are not adjacent to vertex vi‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëñv^{*}_{i}, is extracted and considered for the next vertex selection process. Second, we select a new minimum weight vertex vi‚Ä≤‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëñ‚Ä≤v^{*}_{i^{\prime}} (i.e., vi‚Ä≤‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëñ‚Ä≤v^{*}_{i^{\prime}} should be in the corresponding set of vi‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëñv^{*}_{i}) from subgraph ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚àó)ùí¢superscriptŒì\mathcal{G}(\Gamma^{*}). Now, Œì‚àó={vi‚àó,vi‚Ä≤‚àó}superscriptŒìsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùë£superscriptùëñ‚Ä≤\Gamma^{*}=\{v^{*}_{i},v^{*}_{i^{\prime}}\}. We repeat this process until no further vertex is not adjacent to all vertices in Œì‚àósuperscriptŒì\Gamma^{*}. The selected ùô≤ùô≤\mathtt{C} contains at most Z‚ÄãKùëçùêæZK vertices. Essentially, any possible solution Œì‚àó={v1‚àó,v2‚àó,‚ãØ,vZ‚ÄãK‚àó}superscriptŒìsubscriptsuperscriptùë£1subscriptsuperscriptùë£2‚ãØsubscriptsuperscriptùë£ùëçùêæ\Gamma^{*}=\{v^{*}_{1},v^{*}_{2},\cdots,v^{*}_{ZK}\} to P1 represents a feasible UD-UAV/RRB scheduling.

V-B Solution to Subproblem P2: D2D Graph Construction

In this subsection, our main focus is to schedule the non-LOS UDs to the LOS UDs (relays) over their idle times so as the local models of those non-LOS UDs can be forwarded to the UAVs. Since non-LOS UDs communicate with their respective relays over D2D links, the D2D connectivity can be characterized by an undirected graph ùí¢‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞)ùí¢ùí±‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}) with ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V} denoting the set of vertices and ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} the set of edges. We construct a new D2D conflict graph that considers all possible conflicts for scheduling non-LOS UDs on D2D links, such as transmission and half-duplex conflicts. This leads to feasible transmissions from the potential D2D transmitters |ùí∞non,tra|subscriptùí∞non,tra|\mathcal{U}_{\text{non,tra}}|.

Recall ùí∞nonsubscriptùí∞non\mathcal{U}_{\text{non}} is the set of non-LOS UDs, i.e., ùí∞non=ùí∞\ùí∞l‚Äão‚Äãssubscriptùí∞non\ùí∞subscriptùí∞ùëôùëúùë†\mathcal{U}_{\text{non}}=\mathcal{U}\backslash\mathcal{U}_{los}, and let ùí∞relay=ùí∞los\{u}subscriptùí∞relay\subscriptùí∞losùë¢\mathcal{U}_{\text{relay}}=\mathcal{U}_{\text{los}}\backslash\{u\} denote the set of relays that can use their idle times to help the non-LOS UDs. Hence, the D2D conflict graph is designed by generating all vertices for u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u}-th possible relay, ‚àÄu¬Ø‚ààùí∞relayfor-all¬Øùë¢subscriptùí∞relay\forall\bar{u}\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{relay}}. The vertex set ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V} of the entire graph is the union of vertices of all users. Consider, for now, generating the vertices of the u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u}-th relay. Note that u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u}-th relay can help one non-LOS UD as long as it is in the coverage zone is capable of delivering the local model to the scheduled UAV within its idle time. Therefore, each vertex is generated for each single non-LoS UD that is located in the coverage zone of the u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u}-th relay and ùöÉu^‚â§Ti‚Äãd‚Äãl‚Äãeu¬ØsubscriptùöÉ^ùë¢subscriptsuperscriptùëá¬Øùë¢ùëñùëëùëôùëí\mathtt{T}_{\hat{u}}\leq T^{\bar{u}}_{idle}. Accordingly, iùëñi-th non-LOS UD in the coverage zone ùíµu¬Øsubscriptùíµ¬Øùë¢\mathcal{Z}_{\bar{u}} can transmit its model to the u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u}-th relay. Therefore, we generate |ùíµu¬Ø|subscriptùíµ¬Øùë¢|\mathcal{Z}_{\bar{u}}| vertices for the u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u}-th relay.

All possible conflict connections between vertices (conflict edges between circles) in the D2D conflict graph are provided as follows. Two vertices viu¬Øsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùëñ¬Øùë¢v_{i}^{\bar{u}} and vi‚Ä≤u‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë£superscriptùëñ‚Ä≤superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤v_{i^{\prime}}^{u^{\prime}} are adjacent by a conflict edge in ùí¢d2dsubscriptùí¢d2d\mathcal{G}_{\text{d2d}}, if one of the following conflict conditions is true: (i) (u¬Ø‚â†u‚Ä≤¬Øùë¢superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤\bar{u}\neq u^{\prime}) and (i=i‚Ä≤ùëñsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤i=i^{\prime}). The same non-LoS UD cannot be scheduled to two different helpers u¬Ø¬Øùë¢\bar{u} and u‚Ä≤superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤u^{\prime}. (ii) (i‚â†i‚Ä≤ùëñsuperscriptùëñ‚Ä≤i\neq i^{\prime}) and (u¬Ø=u‚Ä≤¬Øùë¢superscriptùë¢‚Ä≤\bar{u}=u^{\prime}). Tow different non-LoS UDs can not be scheduled to the same relay. These two conditions represent C3 in P2, where each non-LoS UD must be assigned to one relay and the same relay cannot accommodate more than one non-LoS UD. Given the aforementioned designed D2D conflict graph, the following theorem reformulates the subproblem P3.
Theorem 3. The subproblem of scheduling non-LOS UDs on D2D links in P‚Äã2ùëÉ2P2 is equivalently represented by the MWIS selection among all the maximal sets in the ùí¢d2dsubscriptùí¢d2d\mathcal{G}_{\text{d2d}} graph, where the weight œà‚Äã(viu¬Ø)ùúìsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùëñ¬Øùë¢\psi(v_{i}^{\bar{u}}) of each vertex viu¬Øsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùëñ¬Øùë¢v_{i}^{\bar{u}} is given by œà‚Äã(viu¬Ø)=r.ùúìsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùëñ¬Øùë¢ùëü\psi(v_{i}^{\bar{u}})=r.

VI Numerical Results

For our simulations, a circular network area having a radius of 400400400 meter (m) is considered. The height of the CPS is 101010 m [40]. Unless specified otherwise, we divide the considered circular network area into 555 target locations. As mentioned in the system model, each target location is assigned to one UAV where the locations of the UAVs are randomly distributed in the flying plane with altitude of 100100100 m. The users are placed randomly in the area. In addition, UùëàU users are connected to the UAVs through orthogonal RRBs for uplink local model transmissions. The bandwidth of each RRB is 222 MHz. The UAV communicates with the neighboring UAVs via high-speed mmWave communication links [31, 25].

Our proposed FedMod scheme is evaluated on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, which are well-known benchmark datasets for image classification tasks. Each image is one of 101010 categories. We divide the dataset into the UDs‚Äô local data ùíüusubscriptùíüùë¢\mathcal{D}_{u} with non-i.i.d. data heterogeneity, where each local dataset contains datapoints from two of the 101010 labels. In each case, ùíüusubscriptùíüùë¢\mathcal{D}_{u} is selected randomly from the full dataset of labels assigned to uùë¢u-th UD. We also assume non-iid-clustering, where the maximum number of assigned classes for each cluster is 666 classes. For ML models, we use a deep neural network with 333 convolutional layers and 111 fully connected layer. The total number of trainable parameters for MNIST is 9,09890989,098 and for CIFAR-10 is 21,8402184021,840. We simulate an FedMod system with 303030 UDs (for CIFAR-10) and 202020 UDs (for MNIST) and 555 UAVs each with 777 orthogonal RRBs. In our experiments, we consider a network topology that is illustrated in Fig. 3 unless otherwise specified. The remaining simulation parameters are summarized in TABLE I and selected based on [13, 40, 42, 34, 41]. To showcase the effectiveness of FedMoD in terms of learning accuracy and energy consumption, we consider the Star-based FL and HFL schemes.

We show the training accuracy with respect to number of iterations for both the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets with different model dissemination rounds Œ±ùõº\alpha in Fig. 4. Specially, in Figs. 4(a) and 4(b), we show the accuracy performance of our proposed FedMoD scheme with full dissemination against the centralized FL schemes. Particularly, in the considered star-based and HFL schemes, the CPS can receive the local trained models from the UDs, where each scheduled UD transmits its trained model directly to the CPS (in case of star-based FL) or through UAVs (in case of HFL). Thus, the CPS can aggregate all the local models of all the scheduled UDs. In the considered decentralized FedMoD, before the dissemination rounds starts, each UAV has aggregated the trained local models of the scheduled UDs in its cluster only. However, with the novel dissemination FedMoD method, each UAV shares its aggregated models with the neighboring UAVs using one hop transmission. Thus, at each dissemination round, UAVs build their side information (Known models and Unknown models) until they receive all the Unknown models. Thus, the UAVs have full knowledge about the global model of the system at each global iteration. Thanks to the efficient FedMoD dissemination method, the accuracy of the proposed FedMoD scheme is almost the same as the centralized FL schemes. Such efficient communications among UAVs accelerate the learning progress, thereby FedMoD model reaches an accuracy of (0.9450.9450.945, 0.6680.6680.668 for MNIST and CIFAR-10) with around 200200200 and 300300300 global iterations, respectively, as compared to the accuracy of (0.9550.9550.955, 0.9440.9440.944 for MNIST) and (0.6650.6650.665, 0.6680.6680.668 for CIFAR-10) for star-based and HFL schemes, respectively. It is important to note that although our proposed overcomes the struggling UD issue of the star-based scheme and the two-hop transmission of the HFL, it needs a few rounds of model dissemination. However, the effective coding scheme of the models minimizes the number of dissemination rounds. In addition, due to the high communication links between the UAVs, the dissemination delay is negligible which does not affect the FL time.

In Figs. 5(a) and 5(b), we further study the impact of the number of dissemination rounds Œ±ùõº\alpha on the convergence rate of the proposed FedMoD scheme for both the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. For both figures, we consider the following three proposed schemes: (i) FedMoD scheme-full dissemination where UAVs perform full model dissemination at each global iteration, (ii) FedMoD scheme - Œ±=2ùõº2\alpha=2 where partially dissemination is performed and after each 222 complete global iterations, we perform full dissemination, and (iii) FedMoD scheme - Œ±=3ùõº3\alpha=3 where partially dissemination is performed and after each 333 complete global iterations, a full dissemination is performed. From Figs. 5(a) and 5(b), we observe that a partial dissemination with less frequent full dissemination leads to a lower training accuracy within a given number of training iterations. Specifically, the accuracy performance for full dissemination, Œ±=2ùõº2\alpha=2 and 333 schemes is 0.966,0.66,0.750.9660.660.750.966,0.66,0.75 for MNIST and 0.668,0.52,0.590.6680.520.590.668,0.52,0.59 for CIFAR-10, respectively. Infrequent inter-cluster UAV dissemination also leads to un-stable convergence since the UAVs do not frequently aggregate all the local trained models of the UDs.

In Figs. 6(a) and 6(b), we show the test error with respect to number of iterations for both the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets with different model dissemination rounds Œ±ùõº\alpha. It can be observed that, the test error of the proposed FedMod model drops rapidly at the early stage of the training process, and converges at around 160160160 iterations. On the other hand, the training progress of FedMoD model with infrequent full model dissemination (i.e., Œ±=2ùõº2\alpha=2, Œ±=3ùõº3\alpha=3) lags far behind due to the insufficient model averaging of the UAVs, which is due to infrequent full communications among them. As result, both schemes do not converge and suffer higher testing loss compared to full dissemination of the FedMoD scheme since the communication among edge servers in the full dissemination is more efficient and thus accelerates the learning progress.

We also evaluate the learning accuracy of FedMoD on different network topologies of the UAVs as shown in Fig. 7(a). We consider fully connected network where all the UAVs are connected and partially connected network where UAV 444 is not connected to UAV 111. In this figure, we perform 444 different rounds of dissemination. As shown in Fig. 7(b), we see that within a given number of global iterations, a more connected network topology achieves a higher test accuracy. This is because more model information is collected from neighboring UAVs in each round of inter-UAV model aggregation. It is also observed that when Œ±ùõº\alpha is greater than 444, the test accuracy of the partially connected network can approach the case with a fully-connected network. Therefore, based on the network topology of UAVs, we can choose a suitable value of Œ±ùõº\alpha to balance between the number of inter-cluster UAV aggregation and learning performance.

In Fig. 8, we plot the energy consumption of the proposed and benchmark schemes versus the number of UDs for a network of 444 UAVs and 444 RRBs per UAV. From the objective function of problem P1, we can observe that an efficient radio resource management scheme leads to a lower energy consumption. Hence, from Fig. 8, we observe that for FedMoD, the average energy consumption is minimized. Such an observation is because the proposed schemes judiciously allocate LOS UDs to the UAVs and their available RRBs as well as D2D communications. In particular, the random scheme has the largest energy consumption because it randomly schedules the UDs to the UAVs and their available RRBs. Accordingly, from energy consumption perspective, it is inefficient to consider a random radio resource management scheme. From Fig. 8, it is observed that the proposed centralized scheduling FedMoD and distributed FedMoD schemes offer the same energy consumption performances for the same number of UDs. Such an observation can be explained by the following argument. When we have a large number of UDs, the probability that a UD is scheduled to more than one UAV decreases. As a result, the conflict among UAVs and the likelihood of scheduling UDs to the wrong UAV decreases. As an insight from this figure, a distributed radio resource management scheme is a suitable alternative for scheduling the LOS UDs to the UAVs, especially for large-scale networks.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we developed a novel decentralized FL scheme, called FedMoD, which maintains convergence speed and reduces energy consumption of FL in mmWave ATINs. Specifically, we proposed a FedMoD scheme based on inter-cluster UAV communications, and theoretically proved its convergence. A rate-adaptive and D2D-assisted RRM scheme was also developed to minimize the overall energy consumption of the proposed decentralized FL scheme. The presented simulation results revealed that our proposed FedMoD achieves the same accuracy as the baseline FL scheme while substantially reducing energy consumption for convergence. In addition, simulation results reveal various insights concerning how the topology of the network impacts the number of inter-cluster UAV aggregations required for the convergence of FedMoD.

Appendix A Proof of Lemma¬†1

By applying the global loss function to both sides of (12) and using the L-smoothness assumption, we have:

ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t+1))]‚â§ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t))]+ùîº‚Äã‚ü®‚ñΩ‚ÄãF‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t)),‚àíŒª‚ÄãùêÜ‚Äã(t)‚Äãùê¶‚ü©ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπ~ùêÆùë°1ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπ~ùêÆùë°ùîº‚ñΩùêπ~ùêÆùë°ùúÜùêÜùë°ùê¶\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t+1))]\leq\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))]+\mathbb{E}\bigg{\langle}\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t)),-\lambda{\mathbf{G}}(t)\mathbf{m}\bigg{\rangle}

ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t+1))]=ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t))]‚àíŒª‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚ü®‚ñΩ‚ÄãF‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t)),‚ñΩ‚ÄãùêÖ~‚Äã(t)‚Äãùê¶‚ü©ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπ~ùêÆùë°1ùîºdelimited-[]ùêπ~ùêÆùë°ùúÜùîº‚ñΩùêπ~ùêÆùë°‚ñΩ~ùêÖùë°ùê¶\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t+1))]=\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))]-\lambda\mathbb{E}\bigg{\langle}\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t)),\triangledown\tilde{\mathbf{F}}(t)\mathbf{m}\bigg{\rangle}

where Œª2‚ÄãL2ùîº‚à•ùêÜ(t)ùê¶‚àí‚ñΩùêÖ~(t)ùê¶+‚ñΩùêÖ~(t)ùê¶‚à•22=Œª2‚ÄãL2ùîº‚à•ùêÜ(t)ùê¶‚àí‚ñΩùêÖ~(t)ùê¶‚à•22+Œª2‚ÄãL2ùîº‚à•‚ñΩùêÖ~(t)ùê¶‚à•22\frac{\lambda^{2}L}{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}{\mathbf{G}}(t)\mathbf{m}-\triangledown\tilde{\mathbf{F}}(t)\mathbf{m}+\triangledown\tilde{\mathbf{F}}(t)\mathbf{m}\bigg{\lVert}^{2}_{2}=\frac{\lambda^{2}L}{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}{\mathbf{G}}(t)\mathbf{m}-\triangledown\tilde{\mathbf{F}}(t)\mathbf{m}\bigg{\lVert}^{2}_{2}+\frac{\lambda^{2}L}{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\triangledown\tilde{\mathbf{F}}(t)\mathbf{m}\lVert^{2}_{2}. =ùîº‚Äã[F‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t))]‚àíŒª‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚ü®‚ñΩ‚ÄãF‚Äã(ùêÆ~‚Äã(t)),‚àëu=1Ui‚Äãn‚Äãvmu‚Äã‚ñΩ‚ÄãFi‚Äã(ùê∞~u‚Äã(t))‚ü©absentùîºdelimited-[]ùêπ~ùêÆùë°ùúÜùîº‚ñΩùêπ~ùêÆùë°superscriptsubscriptùë¢1subscriptùëàùëñùëõùë£subscriptùëöùë¢‚ñΩsubscriptùêπùëñsubscript~ùê∞ùë¢ùë°\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))]-\lambda\mathbb{E}\bigg{\langle}\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t)),\sum_{u=1}^{U_{inv}}m_{u}\triangledown F_{i}(\mathbf{\tilde{w}}_{u}(t))\bigg{\rangle}

From Assumption 3, we have ùîº‚à•g(ùê∞~u(t))‚àí‚ñΩFu(ùê∞~u(t))‚à•22‚â§œÉ2\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}g(\mathbf{\tilde{w}}_{u}(t))-\triangledown F_{u}(\mathbf{\tilde{w}}_{u}(t))\bigg{\lVert}^{2}_{2}\leq\sigma^{2}. With such a constraint, we can have

ùîº[F(ùêÆ~(t+1))]‚â§ùîº[F(ùêÆ~(t))]‚àí(Œª2‚à•‚ñΩF(ùêÆ~(t))‚à•22\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t+1))]\leq\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))]-\bigg{(}\frac{\lambda}{2}\lVert\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))\lVert^{2}_{2}
+Œª2ùîº‚à•‚àëu=1Ui‚Äãn‚Äãvmu‚ñΩF(ùêÆ~u(t))‚à•22‚àíŒª2ùîº‚à•‚ñΩF(ùêÆ~(t))\displaystyle+\frac{\lambda}{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}\sum_{u=1}^{U_{inv}}m_{u}\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}_{u}(t))\bigg{\lVert}^{2}_{2}-\frac{\lambda}{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))

‚â§ùîº[F(ùêÆ~(t))]‚àí(Œª2‚à•‚ñΩF(ùêÆ~(t))‚à•22+Œª2ùîº‚à•‚àëu=1Ui‚Äãn‚Äãvmu‚ñΩF(ùê∞~u(t))‚à•22\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))]-\bigg{(}\frac{\lambda}{2}\lVert\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))\lVert^{2}_{2}+\frac{\lambda}{2}\mathbb{E}\bigg{\lVert}\sum_{u=1}^{U_{inv}}m_{u}\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{w}}_{u}(t))\bigg{\lVert}^{2}_{2}

‚â§ùîº[F(ùêÆ~(t))]‚àíŒª2‚à•‚ñΩF(ùêÆ~(t))‚à•22‚àí(Œª2‚àíŒª2‚ÄãL2)Q~\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))]-\frac{\lambda}{2}\lVert\triangledown F(\mathbf{\tilde{u}}(t))\lVert^{2}_{2}-\bigg{(}\frac{\lambda}{2}-\frac{\lambda^{2}L}{2}\bigg{)}\tilde{Q}

(A.1)
